texts.shortText:
Bizarre animals sometimes referred to as ‘sea-spiders’ since both groups have 4 pairs of usually elongate, slender legs. However, as they are not closely-related to true spiders, we prefer the term pycnogonids. The body consists of a head with a tubular proboscis, usually a pair of grasping chelicerae, a pair of sensory palps and a pair of ovigerous legs. The latter are unique to this group and used both for grooming, as well as used by males to carry the eggs. Behind the head is an elongate trunk consisting of approximately four segments, each of which bears large lateral processes to which the legs are attached. At the end of the trunk is a small, usually conical, abdomen.

This species is easily identified as the head lacks chelicerae and because it has a compact, almost circular trunk, a very large forward-directed proboscis and relatively short legs.

Global: West coast of Southern Africa to KwaZulu-Natal and St Paul Island.

Local/Regional: Namibia to KwaZulu-Natal.

Very little work has been done on the biology of South African pycnogonids, but this species is relatively commonly seen under boulders and  on rocky shores. Normally occur singly or in pairs moving slowly and ponderously around. Sometimes seen with the enlarged proboscis plunged into the column of a sea-anemone.

The very large proboscis and lack of chelicerae in this species suggest an unusual sectorial mode of feeding and they have been seen with the proboscis plunged into the columns of sea anemones. However, it is not known whether this is the only mode of feeding.

Pycnogonids have unusual reproductive habits.  The sexes are separate and since the body is so narrow, the gonads extend into the legs. The femurs of females may thus become conspicuously enlarged when gravid. There are reproductive openings on all the legs of females and on legs 2 and 4 of males. As the female releases her eggs these are fertilised by the male, who then gathers them up and carries them in a spherical mass attached to his ovigerous legs until they hatch.
There are several other small white pycnogonids in the intertidal in this region, but the lack of chelicerae, large proboscis and short body of this species make it unmistakable.
Branch, G, Griffiths, CL, Branch, M & Beckley, L (2016). Two Oceans: A Guide to the Marine Life of Southern Africa. (Fourth edition) Struik Nature, Cape Town (p. 78).
